title: FBI agents search D.C. Department of Consumer and Regulatory Affairs
text:
The employee, whom city officials did not identify, has been placed on administrative leave.

D.C. Council Chairman Phil Mendelson (D) said he had been told that the FBI visited the sprawling city agency responsible for housing code enforcement and occupational licensing.

“I heard they showed up, and my impression is it involves one employee,” Mendelson said in an interview.

FBI Washington Field Office spokeswoman Melanie Lowry would confirm only “court-authorized law enforcement activity” at the DCRA office. A D.C. police spokesman said city police were not involved.

DCRA Director Ernest Chrappah did not immediately respond to a request for comment, and his spokesman referred questions to the mayor’s office.

In recent years, federal officials have prosecuted DCRA employees in bribery cases. The agency plays a key role in development projects and businesses.

The DCRA has been under scrutiny for its failure to take action on an illegal rooming house where a man and a 9-year-old boy died in an Aug. 18 fire. A D.C. police officer reported dangerous conditions at the house on Kennedy Street NW to the DCRA in March.

Washington journalist Tom Sherwood first reported news of the FBI appearance.

Spencer S. Hsu contributed to this report.
